title: Bachelorette Australia contestant is under investigation by employers
text:
A Bachelorette Australia contestant is under investigation for alleged breach of conduct from his employer after his appearance on the show (Picture: Facebook/Ten)

A contestant on The Bachelorette Australia is being investigated by his employers after he allegedly breached codes of conduct by appearing on the reality show.

Jess Glasgow, who appeared on the premiere of the latest series, is understood to now be under investigation by Noosa Council. The Aussie had revealed to the Bachelorette, Angie Kent, that he works as a councillor, but had ambitions to run for mayor.

In a statement, the current Mayor of Noosa, Tony Wellington, said that Glasgow’s appearance on the series was not ‘reflective of Noosa Council, nor the wider community’s values’.

The contestant made waves during his appearence on the show’s premiere episode (Picture: Ten)

‘Cr Glasgow did not seek approval from myself and I only found out about his involvement after the show had been recorded,’ the Mayor said according to news.com.au.

The councillor has already made a pretty solid first impression – as a classic reality TV villain. In the premiere episode, he revealed his lack of interest in spending time with the Bachelorette and said that, if offered the 24-hour rose, he would decline it.

Glasgow is now, however, making headlines for his conduct both in and out of the show. In an interview with Australian media personality Ben Fordham, Mayor Wellington also confirmed that Glasgow’s case will be referred to the Office Of The Independent Assessor.

If you thought the councillor from Noosa was “unusual” on ‘The Bachelorette’ last night.. so did the Mayor ! pic.twitter.com/k1HMfZynvC — Ben Fordham (@BenFordham) October 10, 2019

In a separate interview with Sunshine Coast Daily, the contestant and councillor disputed the Mayor’s claims and said he had ‘approval and support’ to enter the dating competition.

‘I do not think I brought Noosa Council or Noosa into disrepute,’ he said. ‘It’s reality television. I did not say anything with malice or anything that was disrespectful.’

It seems as if the Aussie version of the show is just as drama-packed as its American cousin, but we’re betting nothing could ever beat the intense drama of this year’s Bachelorette finale in the States.
